column5: Who is bob Kerr?is he Steve Kerr son?
yah - it's good to be king!!
LOL- more like Steve Kerr's dad than son. He is the guy in my avatar. (in his younger days)...
Gotcha
https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world...ons/ar-AAKSvpq less positive, but moving forward slowly

No one knows what sort of documentation will be required to cross the border so I will be content to wait and see. I'm located less than 3 hrs from Fort Francis so it is an easy trip for me and I usually cross in the middle of the week. I recently took a trip to Hawaii and was required to have a negative 3 day test to avoid a quarantine. Hawaii had a website registration that I had to post my test info to and I received an email copy of the test results. The test process was easy. I stopped by the local Covid testing center and only had to wait for about 5 mins. They preformed the test and I got my results the next afternoon about 36 hours later via email. When we arrived in Kona we exited the plane I showed them the test confirmation on my phone, they took my temp and I was on my way. One of the guys who regularly goes on our several annual trips says he will never take a test or get vaxed so I guess he's out till the border crossing has no Covid protocols.

From the article: "The first step is to allow fully vaccinated individuals currently permitted to enter Canada to do so without the requirement to stay in government-authorized accommodation,"Quote: Originally Posted by BrianinVALast week a Health Canada expert advisory panel published a sort of framework and guiding document for reopening the border and that has created lots of optimism. There's also been a wave of bipartisan momentum building on both sides of the border. And then the G7 Summit is June 11-13 and many are speculating that Trudeau won't want to quarantine after it so there might be a change that's conveniently timed for his return.I'm guessing the "first step" will take place closer to June 13 than June 22.
you will know when it happens when the blue jays play in Toronto
There is a PCR self-test that sells for $55. I full expect inventory to be completely gobbled up if Canada opens while still requiring the PCR.

I have to send my passport in to get Business Visas for China and Thailand so I hope the turnaround is within 6 weeks just in case something does happen which I’m still not sold on for just a tourist with no family or property up north.
https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/art...r-June-22.html key words in article - considering open, plan to be shared in days

This is starting to make some sense and it sounds like it is gaining some steam for sure.. glad to hear it.. I think the digital covid pass seems to make the most sense in terms of gaining access. This would certify that either someone had the vaccine or a negative test just prior to crossing. Keep in mind there is no standardized vaccine pass in the states. All states have something slightly different and there are many different locations doing the vaccines also, so something would have to be done to standardize that. Then the other thing that has to get worked out for Canada is the quarantine issue. Unlikely that most would be willing to do a 3-7 day quarantine for a 5-7 day trip. That is unless the front seat of my boat works as a location to do said quarantine. Despite all of these hurdles.. this is clearly the most reasonable and good news we have heard since about March of 2020 regarding the border situation. I think I can have my gear loaded in about 6 hours.. I wont need much in the way of sleeping quarters.. a good recliner with a roof over my head will do. Keep me posted..
2 tests for 19.99 at Walmart.com (Abbott Laboratories)https://www.walmart.com/ip/BinaxNOW-...ests/142089281

Canada currently requires a PCR test for entry and will not accept an antigen test. The Health Canada proposed land border framework also specifically calls for a PCR test for entry. Hopefully they will considering allowing antigen tests given the lower price and greater availability. Thank you for keeping threads alive. There will be much confusion as things start to reopen and allowing us to bounce ideas off each other here will help fisherman and resort owners work through the many twists and turns that lie ahead.
Yahoo!

Assuming the border does open for US fishermen, it will be interesting to see what happens with those that made alternate plans for 2021/cancelled their 2021 reservation. I imagine the camps will hold their weeks for 2022, but will there be a scramble for openings for the balance of 2021?
When/If that happens its going to be nuts up here.I can't wait.

Prov, I would hope so for the outfitters sake but I wouldn't be too sure about that. Their is a reason most trips are scheduled well in advance. Not everyone is retired with unlimited income like Bob Kerr.. Many will have made new vacation plans and either schedule or finance will preclude this years trip. Now next year? Absolutely. At any rate, as most Americans feel, you deserve whatever good fortune could come your way...
^^ Hey now, everyone is getting along by playing within the rules. Fisherman Ted, I love your optimism and truly hope this season opens soon for you.
I do too, and I hope that the hoops we may need to jump through are manageable.
Hope that road map doesn't have a lot of twist n turns in it

The original Ontario Step 1 state date was slated to be June 14 so it looks like they are ahead of the curve. Well done, Ontario! Just note that this is Ontario's roadmap to reopening and not the border. Official press release here.
I'm getting a little shaggy myself since we chatted ot the barber shop
Well looks like things are about to happen pretty soon. July and august trips might be a go!https://www.bloomberg.com/news/artic...ated-travelers

This could happen before the summer is over. Will it happen by June 22nd? Possibly. To happen, they will have to accept the CDC Vaccination Record Card as proof of vaccination and a negative lab-based PCR test. I don't see how else they can accomplish this within the next few weeks. Without the test, a more complex system will need to be implemented to verify proof of vaccination. That won't happen in months, let alone weeks. Once enough of Canada is fully vaccinated, they will loosen the required negative test and eventually even the vaccination records. Assuming we avoid a fourth wave.
Our group has plans for July and all have been fully vaccinated but to get another PCR test without symptoms might be a deal breaker.
Headache, Sore Throat, Loss of smell.....can't really measure that. It will get you a test.
I wonder if he'll bring his trunks ?

Howdy, Considering Ontario just extended its non-essential border closing with Manitoba I fail to see how this is going to happen. To be clear, I hope that I am wrong, however, this all just seems unlikely. Furthermore, while I can't speak for other states, Ohio is not just going to give me a free Covid test if I have no symptoms or reason to get one especially as I'm already vaccinated. So unless there's a change in the availability of testing and the insurance coverage of non-essential tests, any contingency related to a medical test for COVID-19 is going to be problematic. Take care, Ruddiger

Self-test kits are now available OTC and testing clinics are everywhere. It's not going to be free, but the self-test kits are very affordable and will get cheaper as more enter the marketplace. Plus the proposed framework suggested that tests should be available on arrival to the border so folks wouldn't necessarily need to do their own test ahead of time. It's important to note that all of this is a proposed framework at the moment and there is no guarantee that this is how things will eventually be implemented. As you mention, the public health situation in Canada will ultimately determine timing of things. It's also important to note that we don't know what the requirements to reenter the US via land border might look like. Below is the proposed recommendations for fully vaccinated non-exempt travellers to Canada:acceptable proof, as defined by the Government of Canada, of authorized vaccination and that sufficient time has passed after the final dose in the vaccine seriesno pre-departure test, quarantine requirement or day 7 testfor surveillance purposes, PCR test on arrival at the border testing station (for land border crossing, a home-sampling kit may be used)
First step to any border re-opening is to allow me to get my hair cut....
Can u get it cut today?even if the person doing it doesn't have a clue how to cut

All barber shops and hair places are closed. My attempt to trim my hair with the beard trimmer was a failure according to the wife, although I did mention with her current hair she's starting to look a lot like my mother in law. (pro tip: never tell your wife she looks like the mother in law). Fortunately my guests (other than PJ) are not really interested in what my hair looks like....
Maybe PJ can cut it when and if he gets there 😂
I don't think Gord wants to go get his scalp stitched up
It would probably be easier to book Mexican fishing trip this year. You can cross back and forth, positive or not and don't even have to use established border crossings!

Last week a Health Canada expert advisory panel published a sort of framework and guiding document for reopening the border and that has created lots of optimism. There's also been a wave of bipartisan momentum building on both sides of the border. And then the G7 Summit is June 11-13 and many are speculating that Trudeau won't want to quarantine after it so there might be a change that's conveniently timed for his return. The seemingly across the board optimism from resort owners here makes me think NOTO might be have recently shared some additional, inside insight.
Wish I could give them alittle inside insight
All you have to do is phone them up and express your thoughts. Easy Peasey.....PjShorthorn
Or send them an email ?
Do you have the number to them?
1-800-dontknowsh*t
Based on that guiding document I’d say things look pretty promising.
Lol you got that right john,I probably just get in trouble if I did talk to someone on the phone,they might give me life sentence from crossing into Ontario

Agreed. It looks very promising for those in the right "group" if those guidelines are adopted. A self-administered test prior to entry to Canada would be a huge step forward. It will be interesting to see what the US lays out for land border entry.
They are setting up a hotel in Ottawa especially for Trudeau and his pose to quarantine in upon to the country.
If a person or groups returning to the US would have to jump through all them hoops......They might as well just call this year a wash too !.........and we'll give er heck next year !
All this sht to go catch a fish,sounds hi- tech to me

I guess we'll just have to wait and see what plan both sides roll out. Maybe the US ultimately decides they have things under good enough control and negative tests won't be needed for reentry?! I wouldn't bet on it though...
Now in the zombie movies the military just shines a light in the eyes and looks for redness,I would think a vaccine paper n passport will do the trick just my thought

The one I saw is called the Binaxnow Covid-19 ag. You go thru their provider eMed. It will/could work but it is a big hoop to jump thru. BrianinVA - I too hope there will be a better way when they reopen the border.

So will we need to be vax’d to get across the border? Wife and I are vaccinated but don’t want to vaccinate our 3 kids. If that’s the case then no spring trip for my kids anymore. I’ll be good as I would still go up in the fall without the kids!!! 😀
Great attitude.
Fisherman Ted, I hope you are not full of baked beans.
I believe next week we will all be pleasantly surprised -FY
Why what's going to happen?
I cant see opening one without the other ?

All my group, from young to old, will be fully vaccinated, if not already, by the time out late September/early October trip rolls around. Recently, visiting my 97 year old mother-in-law required a self administered cotton swab test up the nose that takes 15 minutes. Thank God it's self administered and doesn't require a second person bent on reaching brain tissue. This type of test could be available or proof of a recent test might suffice. I'm hoping for the best.

Thanks Obabikon for this information. It's very helpful. I have potential trips with my son to SASK and the NWT for late summer that I had assumed would not and could not happen. My son and I have made alternate travel and fishing plans, but now I will watch carefully to see if there is a chance we could get to into Canada for these trips. I don't have plane tickets for those Canada trip, so if the border opens, it will create a scramble.
I believe the border will be open this summer. Fairly soon. So much so that I am finishing up my staffing as I type this and will be fully operational in less than a week. That's all I'm saying -FT
If your going to fish LOW July 4 on the Canadian side,you may have to parachute down with your gear in hand
The last day of summer is sept 22,I hope Ted is right
Canadians can currently fly to the US but Americans can't fly to Canada at the moment. So there is precedent for an unilateral opening.

I too have been concerned on how the Provincial reopening plans/phases would affect the border reopening. I would assume the feds can overrule the provinces if push came to shove? or they would try to work out a compromise. As far as the US requiring a test to return. The CDC guidelines allow rapid tests & results as long as they are verified thru a provider. You can get them in the US and bring the test kit into Canada with you. See the CDC guidelines. I know it's still a looong shot(maybe 20%) but I am still holding out hope for the border to be safely reopened by July 8th.
Canadians have been able to fly into the US for many months now.

Self-administered tests for return to the US would still require a telehealth visit with a provider affiliated with the manufacturer of the test. Are you aware of a manufacturer that also offer the telehealth services? And if so, where's the best place between Red Lake and Fort Frances that would have an internet connection good to conduct a telehealth visit via video?

While June 22 remains a ways away still, I am hard pressed to imagine international borders opening while provincial borders such as Ontario/Manitoba remain closed. Hopefully that changes with Ontario's phase 1, but Manitoba is currently in worse shape than Ontario so it may be more dependent on them. Regardless you have to feel horrible for another season of camp owners being strung along
Hopefully this happens. One of my fishing partners is too young for the shots. Anything positive is good news.

The logistics seem tight. Get covid test June 23 Get test results June 25, buy fishing license and two year conservation card Drive to border late June 25 from Des Moines Sleep 4 hours at motel in International Falls Show test results, passport, and vacination card to border guard with a smile Can you buy fishing license and con card at sports store in Ft. Francis? Just in case we can't cross border.
If your in Fort Francis you've already crossed the border ?

An outdoor card + 8 day conservation fishing license is less than $33 USD. Buy it and consider it a donation to Ontario's MNR if you can't cross. I'd be more worried about the cost of testing (potentially both ways) and where you are going to find a bed in NW Ontario on a Friday night if you happen to test positive on your return trip.
It doesn't get any clearer than that,good post
lol.lol
All I want to know is will I be fishing lake of the woods July 4th weekend

I called our lodge in Manitoba this morning to check the status, and they said that they have also heard the rumors of some type of change by June 22, but said that there is next to zero chance of Manitoba being open by then with the current situation there where they are still sending ICU patients to other provinces. Even if the international border opens in some form, he said that lodges in Manitoba would not be able to open for the foreseeable future.

The last information I saw was that it was only the U.S. side of the border was going to open, allowing Canadians to cross into the U.S. . The Canadian side would remain closed to U.S. citizens and returning Canadians would be subject to quarantine. Did I miss something?

There have been rumors that June 22 is going to be the day. In the past week, I have heard more positive news behind the scenes then the past 14 months combined.I do not know if it will actually be June 22, but for the first time in a long time, I feel optimistic that we will get at least a couple of months worth of a season.The first wave of people will be required to have a vaccination and also have a negative Covid test (not a rapid test). I don’t want to discuss this, I am just sharing information that I am hearing. That is what it is going to take to be in the first wave of crossers. They probably will eventually open up to everyone, but that could be a few months down the road.Again all of this is rumors, but there is increasing pressure for a semi-opened border. This would be amazing news for the resort industry that has been absolutely decimated.
Great to hear, thanks for the info. Our trip is planned for last week of July. Fingers crossed!

This is all well and good. Steps in the right direction, for sure. I have also read the rumors for fully and partially vaccinated people going to Canada My worry is what restrictions may be in place still on a provincial level. Doesn't Ontario still have restrictions on a campsite or cabin rental, only people from the same house hold may occupy it? I had read that somewhere. When are they lifted or relaxed? Hate to be a party pooper, but they are certainly considerations with the level of virus problems they still have in Ontario and Manitoba.

Am I reading this correctly that people who have been inoculated with the 'vaccine" but test positive with the chicom flu will not be permitted to cross. Did I read that right? Will people who haven't taken the jab who test negative be allowed to cross? Asking for a friend.

Just remember that crossing into Canada is only half the battle as a negative test is also currently required to reenter the US. The easy part would be getting a test state-side. Administering tests to thousands of fishermen who all want to cross back into the US on the same day (or two) of the week is not something NW Ontario is equipped to handle at the moment. And even if the infrastructure can be put in place, the added costs and hoops that have to be jumped through would be a hurdle too high for many. Remember the fallout when passports started being required to cross the border? Not trying to be Debbie Downer here, just trying to highlight some of the challenges ahead. Hopefully NW Ontario can rise to the occasion.

Several excellent questions and comments. Hereâ€™️s what I understandâ€¦Premier Ford is expected to put Ontario into stage one opening plan sometime before June 14. Cabin rentals will be allowed, and resorts will be opened provincewide in that stage.I understand false positives, and other concerns over testing. However COVID-19 is a specific strain, and you must test positive for COVID-19 to come up with a positive result.As a returning citizen, the United States cannot legally reject or deny re-entry. They might be requiring a Covid test for noncitizens to enter. I do not believe this is going to be an issue for returning. I will also add that a negative test alone is not going to get you into Canada. It will require full vaccination.One additional issue is children. At what age will they be allowed to cross without being vaccinated? That is not something I have heard anyone address.Letâ€™️s try to keep emotions and politics out of this thread. Great job so far!
If I can get into Ontario I could care less if the us border turns me back,call the wife and tell her to send me money and I'll send her fillets,perfect

No doubt the "Good ole days" of skipping across and getting a week of hunting or fishing and heading up without care in the world are gone forever.The camps will have full cabins for a while from the aging crowd getting in their final trip or two. Also from the diehards that miss it so much. Then the groups that get turned around because of a positive test from one person in the vehicle, improper testing info, hours and hours of wait time to cross, etc.....all at no fault of the Border, will be the final straw for many never to return and decide to enjoy our many resources in the US with little to no hassles or inconvenience.I sure can't wait to get back up and am hoping for the best, but don't hop in line hungry with a full bladder. Double the waiting times would be lucky I'm guessing. I hope to find out shortly.

Below is the current air arrival policy, so it will be an issue if this is the policy that is applied to land crossings. "The Centers of Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) requires all air passengers entering the United States (including U.S. citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents) to present a negative COVID-19 test, taken within three calendar days of departure or proof of recovery from the virus within the last 90 days." Source: US Department of State.Quote: Originally Posted by ObabikonOne additional issue is children. At what age will they be allowed to cross without being vaccinated? That is not something I have heard anyone address.It's something that's on my mind as two of my fishing partners aren't of vaccine eligible age and we have August reservations.
Finally
